conclusion: As shown in the figure, the lower end of the vertical light spring B is fixed on the horizontal surface, and the upper end is connected to A. Initially, A is at rest. The mass of A is m=2kg, and the spring constant of spring B is k1=200N/m. A thin rope passes over a fixed pulley to connect object A to another light spring C with a spring constant of k2. When spring C is in the horizontal position and not deformed, its right endpoint is at position a, and the light rope on the upper end of A is just vertically straight. When the right endpoint of spring C is slowly pulled horizontally to position b, the tension force of spring B on object A is exactly equal to the gravitational force of A. It is known that ab=60cm. During this process, the height that object A rises and the stiffness coefficient k2 of the light spring C are both considered.

The image depicts a setup with a pulley system. Object A, with a mass of 2 kg, is attached to a vertical spring B with a spring constant of 200 N/m. A thin rope connects A to another spring C. Spring C has a stiffness coefficient k2 and is initially in the horizontal position. When spring C is pulled horizontally by ab = 60 cm, the tension in spring B equals the gravitational force on A.

premise: Initially, the system is at rest, and the springs are not deformed.
conclusion: When spring C is pulled horizontally by ab = 60 cm, the tension in spring B equals the gravitational force on A. This implies k1 x = mg, where x is the compression of spring B.
The vertical displacement of A (Δy) is calculated using the Pythagorean theorem: Δy = sqrt((0.6)^2 - (0.098)^2) = 0.6 m.

premise: The potential energy stored in spring C is converted into the potential energy gained by A.
